title: Job Chapter 34 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Job chapter 34 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Job Chapter 34 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Job Chapter 34.

questions.question: Who answers in Job Chapter 34?
questions.explanation: Elihu is the one who answered and spoke in this chapter as stated in Job 34:1.

questions.question: According to Job 34:2, who is Elihu addressing?
questions.explanation: Elihu calls upon the wise men and those with knowledge to hear his words as described in Job 34:2.

questions.question: What does Elihu compare the ear to in Job 34:3?
questions.explanation: Elihu says the ear tests words as the mouth tastes meat in Job 34:3.

questions.question: What does Elihu say about Job's claim in Job 34:5?
questions.explanation: Elihu recounts that Job said, 'I am righteous' as found in Job 34:5.

questions.question: Who does Elihu say Job walks with in Job 34:8?
questions.explanation: Job is described as walking in company with workers of iniquity and wicked men in Job 34:8.

questions.question: According to Job 34:10, what is far from God?
questions.explanation: Elihu states it is far from God to do wickedness or for the Almighty to commit iniquity as in Job 34:10.

questions.question: According to Job 34:11, what does God render to every man?
questions.explanation: God will render to every man according to his ways as stated in Job 34:11.

questions.question: What question does Elihu ask about who governs in Job 34:17?
options: Shall he that hateth right govern?
Who shall be the next king?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall he that hateth right govern?
questions.explanation: Elihu asks if one who hates right should govern, found in Job 34:17.

questions.question: In Job 34:19, Elihu says God does not accept the persons of who?
questions.explanation: God does not accept the persons of princes nor regard the rich more than the poor according to Job 34:19.

questions.question: What happens to mighty men according to Job 34:24?
questions.explanation: God will break in pieces mighty men without number and set others in their place as in Job 34:24.

questions.question: True or False: Job 34:23 states that God will lay more than right upon man in judgment.
questions.explanation: The verse says God will not lay upon man more than right in judgment (Job 34:23).

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 34:28, God hears the cry of the afflicted.
questions.explanation: Job 34:28 states that God hears the cry of the poor and afflicted.

questions.question: True or False: Job 34:30 says the hypocrite should reign over the people.
questions.explanation: The verse says the hypocrite should not reign, lest the people be ensnared (Job 34:30).

questions.question: Complete this verse from Job 34:31: 'Surely it is meet to be said unto God, I have borne _______, I will not offend any more:'
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'I have borne chastisement, I will not offend any more' in Job 34:31.

questions.question: According to Job 34:35, how does Elihu describe Job's words?
questions.explanation: Elihu says Job has spoken without knowledge and his words lack wisdom in Job 34:35.

medium.title: Job Chapter 34 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Job Chapter 34 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Job 34, what biblical truth would you share about God's justice and righteousness?
options: God never does wickedness or perverts judgment.
God is indifferent to human suffering.
God favors the rich over the poor.
questions.correctAnswer: God never does wickedness or perverts judgment.
questions.explanation: Job 34:10-12 teaches that God does not do wickedness nor pervert judgment; He is just and rewards each person according to their ways.

questions.question: How does Job 34 teach us about trust in God's sovereign control over life and death?
options: God gathers man's spirit and breath, causing all flesh to perish together.
Humans have ultimate control over their life span.
Life and death are random and uncontrolled.
Only kings can influence life and death.
questions.correctAnswer: God gathers man's spirit and breath, causing all flesh to perish together.
questions.explanation: Job 34:14-15 affirms God's sovereignty over life and death, reminding believers to trust His control over all creation.

questions.question: According to Job 34, what attitude should believers have toward God's discipline?
options: Accept chastisement and resolve not to offend anymore.
questions.correctAnswer: Accept chastisement and resolve not to offend anymore.
questions.explanation: Job 34:31-32 encourages believers to acknowledge God's discipline, learn from it, and commit to turning away from sin.

questions.question: A believer doubts whether God truly sees their actions. What does Job 34 say about God's awareness of human behavior?
options: God's eyes are upon the ways of man; He sees all his goings.
God is unaware of hidden sins.
God ignores human actions in darkness.
questions.correctAnswer: God's eyes are upon the ways of man; He sees all his goings.
questions.explanation: Job 34:21-22 clearly states that there is no place where workers of iniquity can hide from God's sight.

questions.question: What does Job 34 teach about God's impartiality in judgment?
options: God does not accept the persons of princes nor favor the rich over the poor.
God favors the wealthy and powerful.
God judges based on social status.
God ignores the poor in judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: God does not accept the persons of princes nor favor the rich over the poor.
questions.explanation: Job 34:19 emphasizes God's impartiality, affirming that all people are His handiwork and judged fairly.

questions.question: When a believer feels unjustly accused, how can Job 34 help them understand God's justice?
options: God renders to every man according to his ways and will not do wickedly.
God punishes without cause or reason.
questions.correctAnswer: God renders to every man according to his ways and will not do wickedly.
questions.explanation: Job 34:11-12 shows that God rewards or disciplines people fairly based on their actions, reassuring believers of His justice.

questions.question: How does Elihu describe Job's attitude toward God and righteousness in Job 34?
options: Job claims to be righteous but also questions the value of delighting in God.
Job fully trusts God without question.
Job ignores God and focuses on wealth.
questions.correctAnswer: Job claims to be righteous but also questions the value of delighting in God.
questions.explanation: Job 34:5 and 34:9 reveal that Job asserts his righteousness yet expresses doubt about the benefit of delighting in God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 34, God will allow hypocrites to reign and ensnare the people.
questions.explanation: Job 34:30 states that God prevents hypocrites from reigning to protect the people from being ensnared.

questions.question: True or False: Job 34 teaches that God hears the cry of the poor and afflicted.
questions.explanation: Job 34:28 confirms that God listens to the cries of the poor and afflicted, demonstrating His compassion.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "When God giveth quietness, who then can ______? and when he hideth his face, who then can behold him?"
questions.explanation: Job 34:29 explains that when God grants peace, no one can cause trouble; emphasizing God's sovereign control over circumstances.

questions.question: How does Job 34 instruct believers to respond to correction and teaching from God?
options: Be willing to learn and cease from iniquity.
questions.correctAnswer: Be willing to learn and cease from iniquity.
questions.explanation: Job 34:32 teaches that when one does not understand, they should be taught and choose to stop doing iniquity.

questions.question: A believer struggles with despair over injustice in the world. How does Job 34 offer hope about God's governance?
options: God breaks mighty men and sets others in their place according to His justice.
God allows wickedness to prosper indefinitely.
God ignores the actions of rulers.
God is powerless over earthly affairs.
questions.correctAnswer: God breaks mighty men and sets others in their place according to His justice.
questions.explanation: Job 34:24-25 reveals God's authority to remove the mighty and establish others, assuring believers of His just rule.

questions.question: What does Job 34 teach about the importance of wisdom and understanding when listening to others?
options: Men of understanding and wise men should listen carefully.
Ignorant people should speak without restraint.
We should dismiss advice from others.
questions.correctAnswer: Men of understanding and wise men should listen carefully.
questions.explanation: Job 34:2 and 34:34 emphasize the value of listening and learning with understanding and wisdom.

questions.question: How does Job 34 encourage believers to view their own words and accusations against God?
options: Speak only what you know and acknowledge God's justice.
questions.correctAnswer: Speak only what you know and acknowledge God's justice.
questions.explanation: Job 34:33-37 warns against speaking without knowledge and rebellion, urging believers to recognize God's righteousness.

questions.question: According to Job 34, what is the result when people turn back from God and refuse to consider His ways?
options: God strikes them as wicked men and they are destroyed.
questions.correctAnswer: God strikes them as wicked men and they are destroyed.
questions.explanation: Job 34:26-27 explains that those who reject God’s ways face destruction as a consequence of their rebellion.

hard.title: Job Chapter 34 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Job Chapter 34.

questions.question: In Job 34, Elihu challenges the notion that God commits iniquity. Which verse explicitly states this claim?
questions.explanation: Job 34:10 declares, 'far be it from God, that he should do wickedness; and from the Almighty, that he should commit iniquity,' emphasizing God's righteousness.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Job 34:3 where it says, 'For the ear trieth words, as the mouth tasteth meat'?
questions.explanation: Job 34:3 uses a simile comparing the ear's testing of words to the mouth tasting food, enhancing sensory understanding.

questions.question: According to Job 34:11, how does God treat the works of men?
options: He renders to a man according to his ways
He judges all men equally without regard to their actions
questions.correctAnswer: He renders to a man according to his ways
questions.explanation: Job 34:11 states God will give each man according to his works, emphasizing divine justice and accountability.

questions.question: The phrase 'Who hath given him a charge over the earth?' in Job 34:13 questions God's authority. Which Old Testament passage similarly acknowledges God's sovereign rule over the earth?
questions.explanation: Psalm 24:1 declares 'The earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof,' paralleling Job 34:13's assertion of God's sovereign authority.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Job 34:20 says, 'In a moment shall they die, and the people shall be troubled at midnight, and pass away: and the mighty shall be taken away without ____.'
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes the suddenness of death, stating the mighty shall be taken away without hand, symbolizing an act beyond human intervention.

questions.question: Which theme in Job 34 is highlighted by the statement in Job 34:23, 'For he will not lay upon man more than right; that he should enter into judgment with God'?
questions.explanation: Job 34:23 stresses that God deals justly with men, not placing an unfair burden or condemning without cause.

questions.question: True or False: According to Job 34:22, the workers of iniquity can hide themselves in darkness or the shadow of death.
questions.explanation: Job 34:22 explicitly states that there is no darkness or shadow of death where workers of iniquity may hide, indicating God's omniscience.

questions.question: In Job 34:15, the phrase 'man shall turn again unto dust' alludes to which creation account in the Bible?
questions.explanation: Genesis 3:19 declares that man returns to dust after death, paralleling Job's meditation on mortality in 34:15.

questions.question: How does Elihu describe Job's attitude towards God in Job 34:9?
options: Job says it profiteth a man nothing to delight himself with God
questions.correctAnswer: Job says it profiteth a man nothing to delight himself with God
questions.explanation: Job 34:9 records Elihu quoting Job’s skeptical claim about delighting in God, highlighting Job’s doubt.

questions.question: What cultural or historical context might explain Elihu's challenge to Job regarding the acceptance of princes and the rich in Job 34:19?
options: Ancient Near Eastern justice emphasized impartiality before God
Kings were considered gods and immune to judgment
Social hierarchy exempted rulers from divine law
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern justice emphasized impartiality before God
questions.explanation: Job 34:19 reflects the belief that God does not show partiality to princes or the rich, consistent with Ancient Near Eastern ideals of divine justice.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term related to 'judgment' is central to the argument in Job 34:12, emphasizing that God does not pervert justice?
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'mishpat' (judgment or justice) underpins the theme in Job 34:12 that God will not do wickedly or pervert judgment.

questions.question: According to Job 34:28, what causes the cry of the poor to come unto God?
options: Because the workers of iniquity turn back from God
questions.correctAnswer: Because the workers of iniquity turn back from God
questions.explanation: Job 34:27-28 explains that those who turn away from God cause suffering, prompting the poor’s cry to reach Him.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'he clappeth his hands among us' in Job 34:37 regarding Job's behavior?
questions.explanation: Clapping hands in this context (Job 34:37) denotes scornful defiance, showing Job's rebellious attitude toward God.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the theme of God’s impartial judgment as emphasized in Job 34:19?
questions.explanation: Acts 10:34 states 'God is no respecter of persons,' echoing Job 34:19’s assertion of impartiality.

questions.question: True or False: In Job 34:31, Elihu suggests it is appropriate to confess to God and vow not to offend again after chastisement.
questions.explanation: Job 34:31 encourages saying to God, 'I have borne chastisement, I will not offend any more,' promoting repentance.

theological.title: Job Chapter 34 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Job Chapter 34 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Elihu in Job 34, what is the nature of God's judgment?
options: God will not do wickedly nor pervert judgment
God is indifferent to human actions
questions.correctAnswer: God will not do wickedly nor pervert judgment
questions.explanation: Job 34:12 states that God will not do wickedly nor pervert judgment, affirming God's perfect justice. This aligns with Deuteronomy 32:4, Psalm 89:14, Romans 2:11, and James 2:1 which portray God as just and impartial in judgment.

questions.question: What does Elihu accuse Job of saying about delighting oneself in God?
questions.explanation: Job 34:9 quotes Job as saying, 'It profiteth a man nothing that he should delight himself with God,' reflecting Job's struggle with the apparent futility of righteousness. This challenges the doctrine of God's goodness seen in Psalm 37:4, Jeremiah 29:11, John 15:10, and Romans 8:28.

questions.question: In Job 34, what reason does Elihu give for why God’s judgment is fair?
options: God accepts no bribes and shows no partiality
God favors the rich and powerful
questions.correctAnswer: God accepts no bribes and shows no partiality
questions.explanation: Job 34:19 explains that God does not accept persons or regard the rich more than the poor, emphasizing His impartiality. This is consistent with Acts 10:34, Romans 2:11, Deuteronomy 10:17, and James 2:1.

questions.question: What consequence does Elihu mention for those who have turned back from God and refused to consider His ways?
options: They are destroyed and struck as wicked men
questions.correctAnswer: They are destroyed and struck as wicked men
questions.explanation: Verses 25-27 describe how God overturns and destroys the wicked because they turned back from Him, which aligns with Psalm 37:38, Proverbs 11:31, Romans 1:18, and Hebrews 10:31 emphasizing the just punishment of the unrepentant.

questions.question: According to Elihu, who does God render work and judgment to?
options: Every man according to his ways
questions.correctAnswer: Every man according to his ways
questions.explanation: Job 34:11 states that God will render every man according to his ways, reflecting the biblical principle of divine retribution found in Ezekiel 18:20, Galatians 6:7, Matthew 16:27, and Revelation 22:12.

questions.question: What does Elihu say about the possibility of hiding from God's eyes?
options: There is no darkness where workers of iniquity may hide
Wicked men can hide in shadows
Only the righteous see God’s eyes
God’s eyes are closed at times
questions.correctAnswer: There is no darkness where workers of iniquity may hide
questions.explanation: Job 34:22 emphasizes that no darkness or shadow of death can hide iniquitous workers from God’s sight. This corresponds with 1 Chronicles 28:9, Psalm 139:7-12, Proverbs 15:3, and Hebrews 4:13 highlighting God's omniscience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elihu says, 'For he will not lay upon man more than _____; that he should enter into judgment with God.'
questions.explanation: Job 34:23 states that God will not lay upon man more than right, indicating God's fairness in judgment. This reflects the biblical teaching of divine justice in Psalm 103:6, Isaiah 45:21, Romans 3:26, and 2 Corinthians 5:10.

questions.question: According to Job 34, what happens when God gives quietness?
questions.explanation: Job 34:29 says when God gives quietness, no one can make trouble, highlighting God’s sovereign control. This aligns with Psalm 46:10, Isaiah 54:10, John 14:27, and Philippians 4:7 on God’s peace and authority.

questions.question: What is the role of the 'men of understanding' according to Elihu in Job 34?
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 34 invite men of understanding to hear Elihu’s words and judge rightly, emphasizing wisdom and discernment. Proverbs 1:5, James 1:5, Ecclesiastes 7:12, and 1 Corinthians 2:14 support the biblical call to wisdom.

questions.question: What does Elihu say about Job’s speech and knowledge?
options: Job has spoken without knowledge and without wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Job has spoken without knowledge and without wisdom
questions.explanation: Job 34:35 critiques Job's words as lacking knowledge and wisdom, emphasizing human limitations apart from God. This is consistent with Proverbs 3:5-7, Isaiah 55:8-9, 1 Corinthians 1:25, and James 3:13.

questions.question: Who, according to Elihu, has God set over the earth or disposed the whole world?
questions.explanation: Job 34:13 asks rhetorically who has given God a charge over the earth, implying God alone is sovereign. This matches Psalm 24:1, Isaiah 45:18, Colossians 1:16, and Revelation 4:11 concerning God's universal sovereignty.

questions.question: What does Elihu urge Job to do if he has done iniquity?
questions.explanation: Job 34:32 encourages learning and ceasing from iniquity if committed, reflecting repentance. This is supported by Proverbs 28:13, Ezekiel 18:21-22, Acts 3:19, and 1 John 1:9 teaching the necessity of repentance.

questions.question: What does Elihu say about the cry of the poor and afflicted?
questions.explanation: Job 34:28 states God hears the cry of the poor and afflicted, affirming His justice and compassion. Psalm 34:17, Proverbs 19:17, Isaiah 1:17, and Matthew 5:4 corroborate God's attentiveness to the needy.

questions.question: What does Elihu say about those who add rebellion to their sin and multiply words against God?
options: They are deserving of trial until the end
questions.correctAnswer: They are deserving of trial until the end
questions.explanation: Job 34:36-37 expresses the desire that Job be tried to the end for his rebellious words against God, emphasizing the seriousness of sin and rebellion. This is consistent with Hebrews 10:26-31, Romans 1:18-32, Psalm 7:11, and Revelation 21:8.

questions.question: What analogy does Elihu use to describe how the ear tests words?
questions.explanation: Job 34:3 uses the analogy that the ear tests words as the mouth tastes meat, illustrating discernment. This metaphor relates to Proverbs 18:13, Matthew 7:24, James 1:19, and 1 Corinthians 14:29 about wisdom and discernment in speech.
